questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient is admitted to the emergency department with symptoms of drowsiness and inattentiveness. He is a known epileptic and on treatment. His wife said the doctor recently increased the dose of antiepileptic to control seizures effectively. Examination by the treating physician reveals he has an ataxic gait and gum hypertrophy. Which antiepileptic is the patient taking?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Phenytoin

Highyeild:

Among the given options of antiepileptic drugs, phenytoin causes gum hypertrophy, and a high dose causes cerebellar symptoms like Ataxia and nystagmus. Phenytoin follows saturation kinetics, in which a constant quantity is eliminated per unit of time. A small increase in dose can result in a large increase in concentration and can result in toxicity. Therefore Phenytoin dosage should not be increased by more than 25- 30mg/day.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B. Sodium valproate causes Anorexia, vomiting, loose motions, and common but mild heartburn. Drowsiness, ataxia, and tremor occur at high doses. Option: C. Carbamazepine produces dose-related neurotoxicity—sedation, dizziness, vertigo, diplopia, and ataxia. But does not cause gum hypertrophy. Option: D. Ethosuximide causes Dose-related side effects - gastrointestinal intolerance, tiredness, mood changes, agitation, headache, drowsiness, and inability to concentrate

questions.text: A patient was put on carbamazepine for GTCS. His seizure episodes were controlled for one month. After one month, he had two episodes of seizures in two following weeks. The next best step is:
questions.correct_answer: A. Increase the dose of carbamazepine
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Increase the dose of carbamazepine

:

Carbamazepine is an enzyme inducer and undergoes auto-induction It induces its metabolism, causing its serum concentration to fall after a few weeks of treatment. The half-life, typically 36 hours after a single initial dose, falls to 8-12 hours in subjects who receive carbamazepine continuously. So in this patient, dose adjustments are required after a few weeks of treatment, and since the seizure is increased, increasing the dose of carbamazepine is the next best step.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B, C, and D is the incorrect option

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: Stop phenytoin and add tab Folic Acid

options.label: D
options.text: Continue with phenytoin and add a tab Folic Acid and during the last two weeks of pregnancy, give oral Vitamin K

questions.correct_answer: D. Continue with phenytoin and add a tab Folic Acid and during the last two weeks of pregnancy, give oral Vitamin K
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Continue with phenytoin and add a tab Folic Acid and during the last two weeks of pregnancy, give oral Vitamin K

Highyeild:

Stopping phenytoin has more risk than continuing it So, guidelines say to continue the antiepileptic (phenytoin or valproate, etc.). The patient is well-controlled on phenytoin and adds folic acid as soon as pregnancy is detected (to decrease NTDS) Oral vitamin K is given to prevent bleeding episodes in newborns, as phenytoin causes vitamin K deficiency NOTE: If the patient is diagnosed with epilepsy during pregnancy and needs to start an antiepileptic drug, then start with the new lamotrigine, which has less NTDS & safer in pregnancy as compared to conventional antiepileptics. Folic acid supplementation should be continued

options.text: Therapeutic plasma concentration of phenytoin is 10-20 µg/ml

questions.correct_answer: C. Phenytoin can be given in both saline and glucose
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Phenytoin can be given in both saline and glucose

:

Fosphenytoin is Given through slow iv infusion to prevent arrhythmias, CV collapse, and coma (ECG monitoring is necessary). Fosphenytoin is a prodrug converted into phenytoin by phosphatases in the liver and red blood cells. Remember: Fosphenytoin can be given in both saline and glucose solutions, but phenytoin gets precipitated in a glucose solution, so not given in a glucose solution. The therapeutic plasma concentration of phenytoin is 10-20 µg/ml

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of a 2-week history of frequent episodes of unresponsiveness. During these episodes, he stares blankly, rhythmically nods his head, and does not respond to verbal stimulation for several seconds. Hyperventilation for 30 seconds precipitates an episode of unresponsiveness and head nodding that lasts for 7 seconds. He regains consciousness immediately afterward. An electroencephalogram shows 3-Hz spikes and waves. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for this patient's condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Blockade of Thalamic T-type calcium channels.

options.label: B
options.text: Inhibition of presynaptic voltage-activated calcium channels.

options.label: D
options.text: Inhibition of GABA reuptake into presynaptic neurons.

questions.correct_answer: A. Blockade of Thalamic T-type calcium channels.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Blockade of Thalamic T-type calcium channels.

:

This boy has childhood absence epilepsy. Absence seizures typically manifest with episodes of staring, inattentiveness, and head nodding and can be triggered by hyperventilation. Patients typically maintain muscle tone during seizures and do not experience a postictal phase. The diagnosis is confirmed with EEG findings of a 3-Hz spike and wave pattern. First-line therapy is ethosuximide.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Blockade of T-type calcium channels in the thalamus is the mechanism of action of ethosuximide, the first-line therapy for seizure prophylaxis in patients with childhood absence epilepsy. T-type calcium channels are thought to be responsible for the rhythmic 3-Hz discharge seen on EEG during absence seizures. Option: B. Inhibition of presynaptic voltage-activated Ca2+ channels is the mechanism of action of gabapentin. This drug is contraindicated in patients with childhood absence epilepsy because it can precipitate absence seizures. Gabapentin is often used to treat focal seizures. Option: C. Blockade of voltage-gated Na+ channels is the mechanism of action of lamotrigine. This drug is a third-line therapy for seizure prophylaxis in patients with childhood absence epilepsy; another drug is more appropriate as first-line therapy. Several other anticonvulsant drugs also act on Na+ channels, including valproic acid (a second-line therapy that increases channel inactivation), carbamazepine (which blocks the channels but is not used because it can precipitate absence seizures), and phenytoin (which blocks the channels but is ineffective in treating absence seizures). Option: D Inhibition of GABA reuptake into presynaptic neurons is the mechanism of action of tiagabine. This drug is contraindicated in patients with childhood absence epilepsy because it can precipitate absence seizures. Tiagabine is often used to treat focal seizures.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man comes to the physician for hematemesis and progressive heartburn over the past five days. Ten days ago, he was started on medication to treat a condition that causes hearing difficulties and pain in the lower legs. He has to manage a serious illness. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 20 years. Physical examination shows bowing of the tibias. An upper endoscopy shows mucosa inflammation and a 1-cm punched-out ulcer in the distal esophagus. Which of the following drugs is the most likely cause of the patient's current condition?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Risedronate This patient's hearing difficulties, bone pain, and tibial bowing raise suspicion for Paget's disease of bone. Heartburn, hematemesis, and an esophageal ulcer after initiating treatment indicate drug-induced esophagitis. Option: B . This patient's drug-induced esophagitis is likely due to oral bisphosphonate therapy (e.g., risedronate). Bisphosphonates, which inhibit osteoclast-mediated bone resorption, are the first-line treatment for Paget’s disease of the bone. Oral bisphosphonates may cause erosive esophagitis and esophageal cancer, especially in patients who do not maintain an upright posture for 30–60 minutes after ingestion. Other side effects of bisphosphonates (both IV and oral) include aseptic osteonecrosis of the jaw, atypical femoral fractures, hypocalcemia, and hypophosphatemia. IV bisphosphonates (e.g., zoledronate) may cause an acute-phase reaction with flu-like symptoms 24–72 hours after administration

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A . Denosumab inhibits osteoclasts and reduces bone resorption. It is administered as a subcutaneous injection to treat osteoporosis. Denosumab is not currently recommended for use in Paget’s disease of bone, and it is not associated with esophagitis.. Option: C. Calcitonin reduces bone resorption and disease activity in Paget’s disease of bone. Because it is less effective than the first-line treatment, it is only used if the first-line therapy After initiating treatment, is poorly tolerated. Calcitonin is administered and does not cause esophagitis. Option: D. Oral prednisolone can cause drug-induced esophagitis, peptic ulcers, and gastrointestinal hemorrhage. However, prednisolone should be avoided in patients with Paget’s disease of bone because prolonged use may lead to osteoporosis and further increase the risk of fragility fractures. Therefore, it is unlikely that this patient was treated with prednisolone.

questions.text: An otherwise healthy 13-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of asthma attacks that have increased in frequency and severity over the past 4 weeks. He was first diagnosed with asthma 6 months ago. Current medications include high-dose, inhaled fluticasone, and salmeterol daily, with additional albuterol as needed. He has required several courses of oral corticosteroids. Medication is added to his therapy regimen that results in the downregulation of the high-affinity IgE receptor (FcεRI) on maAfter initiating treatment, st cells and basophils. Which drugs were most likely added to the patient's medication regimen?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Omalizumab

:

This drug binds free serum IgE, which subsequently leads to the downregulation of FcεRI, preventing the allergen-induced release of inflammatory mediators from mast cells. The drug is reserved as an adjunct agent for patients with moderate to severe asthma whose symptoms are refractory to treatment with inhaled corticosteroids and beta-2 agonists.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Omalizumab is used in treating moderate to severe allergic asthma that is refractory to treatment with inhaled steroids and long-acting β2-agonists. Allergic asthma is caused by the binding of allergen-specific IgE to high-affinity receptors (FCɛRI) on basophils and mast cells. By binding circulating IgE, omalizumab reduces the serum levels of free IgE, which reduces the stimulation of mast cells and basophils and prevents activation of the inflammatory cascade. Over time, reduced serum IgE levels result in the downregulation of FcεRI in these cells. Option: B. Montelukast is a leukotriene receptor antagonist used as prophylaxis in asthma management. This drug inhibits the bronchospastic process initiated by proinflammatory leukotrienes by inhibiting leukotriene receptors, specifically in the bronchial smooth muscle cells. It cannot be used to reverse bronchospasm in an acute attack nor cause downregulation of the FcεRI on mast cells and basophils. Option: C. Nedocromil is a mast cell stabilizer that inhibits degranulation, thereby preventing bronchospasm. It is used as a prophylactic medication for asthma but would not reverse bronchospasm in an acute attack. Furthermore, the drug has no effect on the FcεRI on mast cells and basophils. Option: D. Infliximab is an anti-TNF antibody that is commonly used to treat Crohn's disease, ulcerative colitis, and rheumatoid arthritis. It is not indicated for the treatment of asthma, although there are small case series describing its use in this setting. Furthermore, infliximab does not cause downregulation of the FcεRI on mast cells and basophils.

#Mantra

questions.text: An investigator is studying the effects of different drugs on the contraction of cardiomyocytes. The myocytes can achieve maximal contractility with the administration of drug A. The administration of drug B produces the response depicted in the graph shown. Which of the following drugs is most likely to produce a response similar to that of drug B?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Pindolol It is used for treating hypertension (high blood pressure) and angina (heart-related chest pain). It reduces blood pressure and helps in preventing future heart attack and strokes.

Highyeild:

Pindolol is a partial agonist of beta-1 adrenergic receptors. Although partial agonists (drug B) typically have the same effect as complete agonists (drug A), they have a lower efficacy (a lower maximal drug effect). Pindolol would be consistent with drug B in the graph, as the plateau of maximal effect is lower for drug B than for drug A.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B. Propranolol is a reversible competitive antagonist of beta-adrenergic receptors. As a reversible competitive antagonist, it inhibits the effect of a beta-adrenergic agonist, requiring a higher concentration of that agonist to achieve a given efficacy. In other words, a competitive antagonist reduces the potency of a drug but does not affect its efficacy. This would be reflected by shifting the curve on the graph to the right. Option: C. Phenoxybenzamine is a noncompetitive antagonist of alpha-adrenergic receptors. Although the administration of a non-competitive antagonist does reduce the efficacy of a given agonist, this study evaluates the effects of drugs on the contraction of cardiomyocytes. Alpha receptors do not play a significant roattackscardiac muscle contraction. Option: D. Isoproterenol is a full agonist of beta-adrenergic receptors. Administration of this drug would correspond to the tracing for drug A, not drug B.
